expanded_description: Equations and inequalities are fundamental tools in algebra. While they share many solving techniques, the critical difference lies in how we handle the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing by negative numbers. This review section brings together all the concepts from solving equations and inequalities, highlighting similarities, differences, and helping you develop a unified approach to solving both types of problems.

core_concept.principle: Both equations and inequalities are solved by isolating the variable using inverse operations. The key difference: when multiplying or dividing by a negative number, the inequality sign must be flipped, while equations remain unchanged. The solution to an equation is typically a single value (or set of values), while the solution to an inequality is a range of values, often represented on a number line.
core_concept.explanation: Think of equations and inequalities as two sides of the same coin. Equations ask 'what exactly makes this true?' while inequalities ask 'what range makes this true?' The solving process is nearly identical, but inequalities have an extra rule—like a warning label that says 'Caution: Negative numbers flip the sign!'

sections.introduction: Let's start with a quick comparison of how equations and inequalities are solved and represented.

introduction_image.alt: Side-by-side comparison of equation and inequality solving
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.10.2: Comparing equations and inequalities.

key_concept.definition:
| Feature | Equations | Inequalities |
|---------|-----------|--------------|
| Solution | Usually a single value (or set) | Usually a range of values |
| Graphing | Point(s) on number line | Shaded region(s) on number line |
| Negative multiplication/division | No sign change | Flip the inequality sign |
| Special cases | Identity (all real numbers) or contradiction (no solution) | Same special cases |
| Compound forms | Systems of equations | AND/OR compound inequalities |
key_concept.context: This table summarizes the key similarities and differences. Keep it in mind as you work through problems.

image.alt: Comparison table of equations and inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.10.3: Equations vs inequalities comparison.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Equation vs Inequality

image.caption: Figure 6.10.4: Identify each as equation or inequality.

worked_examples.problem:
Classify each as an equation or inequality:
a) $3x + 5 = 14$
b) $2x - 7 > 3$
c) $4(x + 2) \leq 12$
d) $5x - 3 = 2x + 9$
e) $-2 < x < 5$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Equation, b) Inequality, c) Inequality, d) Equation, e) Inequality
worked_examples.concept_applied: The presence of =, <, >, ≤, ≥ determines the type.

sections.section_title: 6.10.2 Review: Solving One-Step Equations and Inequalities
sections.introduction: Let's review one-step problems, noting when the sign-flip rule applies in inequalities.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.10.6: Solving one-step equations and inequalities.

key_concept.definition: For one-step problems, the same inverse operation applies to both equations and inequalities. The only difference: if you multiply or divide an inequality by a negative number, you must flip the inequality sign.
key_concept.context: This is the fundamental rule that sets inequalities apart from equations.

image.alt: Table comparing one-step equation and inequality solving
image.caption: Figure 6.10.7: One-step comparison.

worked_examples.title: One-Step Problems
worked_examples.concept_applied: One-step problems: same operations, but flip inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative.

image.alt: Summary of one-step equations and inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.10.9: One-step review summary.

sections.section_title: 6.10.3 Review: Solving Two-Step Equations and Inequalities
sections.introduction: Two-step problems require undoing addition/subtraction first, then multiplication/division.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.10.10: Solving two-step equations and inequalities.

key_concept.definition: For two-step problems, always undo addition/subtraction first, then multiplication/division. The sign-flip rule applies only during the multiplication/division step, and only if you're multiplying or dividing by a negative number.
key_concept.context: The order of operations is the same for both equations and inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Two-Step Problems
worked_examples.concept_applied: Two-step: undo addition/subtraction first, then multiplication/division, flipping only when dividing by negative.

image.alt: Summary of two-step equations and inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.10.13: Two-step review summary.

sections.introduction: Multi-step problems require distributing, combining like terms, and handling variables on both sides.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.10.14: Solving multi-step equations and inequalities.

key_concept.definition: For multi-step problems: (1) Simplify each side by distributing and combining like terms. (2) Collect variable terms on one side. (3) Isolate the variable term. (4) Multiply/divide to solve. Throughout, remember the sign-flip rule for inequalities when multiplying or dividing by negatives.
key_concept.context: These problems combine all previous skills and require careful organization.

worked_examples.title: Multi-Step Problems
worked_examples.final_answer: a) $x = 1$, b) $x > 3$, c) $x \geq -0.2$, d) $x = -3$, e) No solution
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multi-step problems require careful distribution and combining terms before isolating the variable.

image.alt: Summary of multi-step equations and inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.10.17: Multi-step review summary.

sections.introduction: Both equations and inequalities can have special cases where the variable cancels, leading to all real numbers or no solution.

introduction_image.alt: Special cases in equations and inequalities
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.10.18: Reviewing special cases.

key_concept.definition:
When the variable cancels:
• If the resulting statement is TRUE (e.g., $3 = 3$, $5 > 2$, $-1 \leq 4$), the solution is all real numbers.
• If the resulting statement is FALSE (e.g., $3 = 5$, $5 < 2$, $-1 \geq 4$), there is no solution.
key_concept.context: This applies to both equations and inequalities, but note that what counts as 'true' depends on the equality or inequality sign.

image.alt: Table of special cases for equations and inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.10.19: Special cases comparison.

worked_examples.title: Special Cases Review

image.alt: Equations and inequalities with special cases
image.caption: Figure 6.10.20: Solve each.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) All real, b) No solution, c) All real, d) No solution, e) All real
worked_examples.concept_applied: When variable cancels, check the truth of the remaining statement.

sections.introduction: Compound statements include systems of equations (multiple equations) and compound inequalities (AND/OR).

introduction_image.alt: Systems of equations and compound inequalities
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.10.22: Reviewing compound statements.

key_concept.definition:
• Systems of equations: Find values that satisfy all equations simultaneously. Solutions are intersection points.
• AND compound inequalities: Find values that satisfy both inequalities. Graph is a single interval.
• OR compound inequalities: Find values that satisfy at least one inequality. Graph may be two separate intervals.
key_concept.context: While systems of equations and compound inequalities are different, both involve combining conditions.

worked_examples.title: Compound Statements
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each:
a) System: $2x + y = 10$ and $x - y = 2$
b) AND: $-3 < 2x + 1 < 5$
c) OR: $x < 2$ or $x > 4$
d) AND: $x \geq 0$ and $x \leq 3$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Systems of equations give ordered pairs; compound inequalities give intervals.

sections.introduction: Representing solutions visually helps understand the difference between equation solutions (points) and inequality solutions (regions).

key_concept.definition:
• Equations in one variable: graph as a point on the number line.
• Inequalities in one variable: graph as shaded regions with open/closed circles.
• Systems of equations in two variables: graph as intersection point of lines.
• Compound inequalities: graph as intervals or separate regions.
key_concept.context: Graphing provides a visual check of your solutions and helps understand the meaning of the solution set.

worked_examples.title: Graphing Solutions
worked_examples.problem:
Graph each solution on a number line:
a) $x = 3$
b) $x > -2$
c) $x \leq 1$
d) $-2 < x \leq 4$
e) $x < -1$ or $x > 2$

sections.section_title: 6.10.8 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Let's review the most common errors in solving equations and inequalities, and how to avoid them.

classifications.value: Forgetting to flip the inequality sign when multiplying/dividing by a negative.

characteristics: Not following reverse order of operations

examples.explanation: Correct: Subtract 3 first, then divide by 2

worked_examples.title: Error Identification and Correction
worked_examples.problem: A student solved $3 - 2x \geq 7$ and got $x \geq -2$. Identify and correct the error.
worked_examples.final_answer: Correct: $x \leq -2$. Student forgot to flip the inequality sign when dividing by -2.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always flip when dividing by a negative number.

sections.introduction: Apply all your skills to solve a variety of equations and inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Review Set
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each and graph where appropriate:
1) $3x - 7 = 14$
2) $2x + 5 > 13$
3) $-4x + 3 \leq 11$
4) $5(x - 2) + 3 = 2x + 1$
5) $\frac{x}{3} - 2 \geq 4$
6) $-2 < 3x + 1 < 7$
7) $2x - 5 = 2x + 3$
8) $x < -1$ or $x > 3$
9) Real-world: You have $\$60$ to spend on CDs ($\$12$ each) and DVDs ($\$15$ each). You want at least 2 CDs. Write and solve an inequality for the number of DVDs you can buy if you get 2 CDs.

summary: This review section has compared and contrasted equations and inequalities, highlighting their similarities and critical differences. Both are solved by isolating the variable using inverse operations, following the same order of operations. The key difference is the sign-flip rule: when multiplying or dividing an inequality by a negative number, the inequality symbol must be reversed. One-step, two-step, and multi-step problems follow the same sequence for both equations and inequalities. Special cases occur when the variable cancels—if the resulting statement is true, the solution is all real numbers; if false, there is no solution. Compound statements include systems of equations (solved for ordered pairs) and compound inequalities (solved for intervals using AND or OR). Solutions to equations are typically points on a number line, while inequality solutions are shaded regions. Real-world applications use both equations (exact values) and inequalities (ranges, limits). Mastering both types of problems provides a complete foundation for algebra and prepares students for more advanced topics in mathematics.
